Description: Lump of red pigment, probably red ochre.
Curator's comments: Naturally dyed clay or hydrated iron oxide, red ochre clay was used in Ancient Egypt for various purposes such as painting or make up. The pigment had to be ground and mixed with water. Probably found in the cemetery (from Gardner's season, when other fragments of red ocre were found in a funary context; Oxford, Ashmolean Museum AN1888.193). A small stone mortar was found in 1903 with traces of red ochre (Oxford, Ashmolean Museum AN1896-1908-E.4553), it is not certain whether this was excavated or acquired in 1903 by Hogarth.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (ZA.18)
